Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Low-Dose Intravenous Lidocaine for Postoperative Analgesia in Total Hip Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised, double-blinded trial included 60 patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to receive either lidocaine 1% (lido group) with a 1.5 mg/kg IV bolus followed by a 1.5 mg/kg/h IV infusion or saline (control group).

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate whether a continuous intravenous (IV) low-dose lidocaine infusion reduced postoperative pain and modified nociceptive pain threshold after total hip arthroplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was postoperative analgesia, measured by morphine consumption over 48 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and clinicians were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty patients were randomised, 30 to each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Sixty patients were randomised, 30 to each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Lidocaine did not induce any opioid-sparing effect during the first 24 hours (−2 mg, 95% CI [−5; 9]; p = 0.55).
